15:17 • 1 months ago

HYPR

How Deterministic Security Eliminates Probabilistic Guesswork

When Security Experts Get Phished Even the most seasoned cybersecurity professionals can fall victim to sophisticated phishing attacks. The phishing attack that gained access to Troy Hunt's Mailchimp account isn't just another security incident – it's a brutal wake-up call exposing the inherent weaknesses of probabilistic security and its inability to withstand modern attacks.
When Security Experts Get Phished

Even the most seasoned cybersecurity professionals can fall victim to sophisticated phishing attacks. The phishing attack that gained access to Troy Hunt's Mailchimp account isn't just another security incident – it's a brutal wake-up call exposing the inherent weaknesses of probabilistic security and its inability to withstand modern attacks.

This incident reveals a harsh truth: our current approach to identity security is fundamentally flawed. As digital threats evolve in complexity and scale, the inadequacies of traditional security measures become more apparent. The time has come for a paradigm shift – from probabilistic to deterministic identity assurance.

Why the Troy Hunt Phishing Attack is a Wake-Up Call for MFA Inadequacy

The attack that affected Troy Hunt followed a depressingly familiar pattern. Picture this: a routine day, an innocuous-looking notification from Mailchimp appears in an inbox. Nothing seems out of the ordinary, except this notification was not from Mailchimp at all. It's a masterfully crafted phishing attack designed to appear legitimate down to the smallest detail.

The attackers didn't just gain momentary access. They siphoned sensitive data, including information that Mailchimp had kept long after it served any legitimate purpose. The breach was comprehensive, devastating, and worst of all – preventable.

What makes this incident particularly alarming isn't just that it happened, but how it happened. The supposedly "strong" multi-factor authentication that protected the account crumbled like a sandcastle at high tide. One-time passwords, once the gold standard of additional security factors, proved no match for attackers who have evolved their techniques to intercept and relay these codes in real-time.

This isn't just a story about one breach. It's a story that's repeating with alarming frequency across industries, organizations, and individuals. And it will continue to repeat until we address the core problem.

The Fundamental Problem: Probabilistic vs. Deterministic Security

To understand why our current security models are failing, we need to examine the core philosophical difference between probabilistic and deterministic security approaches.

Probabilistic Security is Educated Guesswork

Traditional security methods (passwords, OTPs, knowledge-based questions, and even many forms of MFA) operate on a probabilistic model. They attempt to infer legitimacy based on factors that suggest, but don't confirm, a user's identity:

Passwords: Assume that only legitimate users know the secret
OTPs: Assume that only legitimate users have access to a particular device or email account
Knowledge-based authentication: Assume that only legitimate users know personal information
Behavioral biometrics: Assume patterns of behavior remain consistent

The fundamental weakness in all these methods is the “assumption”. They work on statistical likelihood rather than certainty, leaving gaps that can be exploited.

Deterministic Security Establishes Certainty

In contrast, deterministic security doesn't rely on assumptions or probabilities. It establishes certainty by verifying immutable factors that definitively prove identity:

Cryptographic verification that mathematically proves possession of private keys Device binding that ensures authentication can only occur from authorized devices Biometric verification (when implemented properly) that confirms physical presence of a user

Why Probabilistic Security Continues to Fail

The shortcomings of probabilistic security models have become increasingly evident as attack techniques evolve in sophistication and scale. Modern phishing has transformed into a high-precision operation that can bypass traditional MFA by capturing credentials and authorization codes in real-time, then replaying them before they expire. This technique renders time-based one-time passwords virtually ineffective when an attacker can intercept and forward them immediately.

Man-in-the-Middle Attacks

Similarly concerning are adversary-in-the-middle attacks, where attackers position themselves invisibly between users and legitimate services. In this position, they can silently capture and relay authentication data without being detected, creating the illusion of security while compromising the entire process.

Credential Stuffing

Despite years of security awareness training, credential stuffing remains devastatingly effective because users continue to reuse passwords across services. This human tendency means credentials leaked from one breach often unlock multiple accounts, amplifying the damage from a single compromise.

Social Engineering

The social aspects of security have proven equally vulnerable. Social engineering has evolved to bypass knowledge-based authentication by gathering personal information from social media and data breaches. Information that was once considered private enough to verify identity, (mother's maiden name, first pet, childhood street) is now readily available to determined attackers.

The fundamental problem becomes clear when examining these vulnerabilities: probabilistic security measures attempt to build higher walls around inherently vulnerable systems, but determined attackers simply develop more sophisticated methods to bypass them. This approach is fundamentally reactive rather than transformative. 

The Path Forward: Deterministic Identity Assurance

The solution to these vulnerabilities lies in embracing a deterministic approach to identity security. This approach removes assumptions and probabilities, replacing them with cryptographic certainty.

The Three Pillars of Deterministic Identity Assurance

A truly effective identity security system must address the entire identity lifecycle through three critical components:

Authentication: Eliminating Phishable Factors and Shared Credentials
The first step is replacing vulnerable authentication methods with truly phishing-resistant alternatives: FIDO Passkeys: Using public-private key cryptography instead of shared secrets, like passwords
Device Binding: Ensuring authentication can only occur from registered, managed, or trusted devices
Biometric Verification: Adding a physical presence requirement that can't be replicated remotely

Adaptive Risk Assessment: Beyond Point-in-Time Verification
Deterministic security doesn't stop at login. It continuously monitors for anomalies throughout the user session:
Behavioral Analysis: Tracking patterns of user behavior to identify deviations
Contextual Signals: Evaluating location, device health, network conditions, and other environmental factors
Risk-Based Policies: Automatically applying appropriate security measures based on detected risk levels

 Identity Verification: Securing the Starting Point
The strongest authentication is meaningless if the original identity verification is compromised:
Document Verification: Validating government-issued IDs or verifiable digital credentials
Biometric Matching: Confirming the user matches their ID
Liveness Detection: Ensuring verification involves a real person, not a spoofed image or deepfake
Implementing Deterministic Security: Real-World Applications

The journey toward deterministic security looks different for every organization, but certain principles remain constant. Let me walk you through how this transformation typically unfolds across different aspects of operations.

For customer-facing applications, the shift begins with reimagining authentication. Gone are the days of password complexity requirements that frustrate legitimate users while doing little to deter attackers. Instead, customers use their devices' built-in biometrics, a fingerprint or facial scan, to unlock cryptographic passkeys that prove their identity without sharing secrets.

The experience feels magical in its simplicity. A customer opening a banking app touches the fingerprint sensor, and they're in – no passwords to remember, no codes to enter. Behind this seamless experience lies rock-solid security: cryptographic verification that mathematically proves the user's identity.

This same mechanism secures high-value transactions. When a customer initiates a significant funds transfer, the same biometric verification confirms their intent, eliminating the fraud that plagues traditional systems.

For workforce security, the transformation touches every aspect of the employee experience. Morning workstation login happens with a tap or glance rather than typing a complex password that changes every 90 days. Remote workforce access to corporate resources occurs through similarly streamlined but vastly more secure mechanisms.

Particularly sensitive is privileged access. Those administrative accounts that hold the keys to the kingdom. Here, deterministic security adds additional contextual checks. An administrator accessing critical systems outside normal hours or from an unusual location might trigger step-up verification or management notification, all without disrupting legitimate work.

The Business Case for Deterministic Security

Beyond the technical advantages, deterministic security provides substantial business benefits that extend beyond the security department.

Organizations implementing deterministic identity assurance have reported significant improvements. For example, the HYPR Total Economic Impact report indicates that organizations can achieve a 324% 3-year ROI by deploying HYPR passwordless MFA.

This includes benefits like:  

Business Risk Avoidance: Organizations can avoid $3,321,036 in business risk, due to an average 80% reduction in passwords. Help Desk Cost Avoidance: There is a 95% reduction in password reset tickets, leading to $3,086,623 in help desk cost avoidance.   End-User Productivity Increase: A 30% faster authentication contributes to an increase in end-user productivity, valued at $3,246,711.   These figures demonstrate that the impact of enhanced security measures goes beyond just preventing breaches. By reducing the burden on IT support and improving user workflows, organizations can reallocate resources to strategic initiatives and improve overall operational efficiency.
The Time for Deterministic Security Is Now

Troy Hunt's experience, while unfortunate, provides invaluable lessons. It underscores the urgent need for a paradigm shift in security – a shift towards deterministic, phishing-resistant solutions. HYPR is at the forefront of this shift, championing passwordless MFA and continuous identity assurance as the future of security.

We commend Troy for being so transparent and forthcoming in sharing the details of this incident. His openness not only demonstrates integrity but also provides critical insights for the entire security community. By walking us through what happened and how it could have been prevented, Troy is helping to raise awareness and drive better practices that can ultimately prevent future attacks like this.

Don't wait for a breach to expose your vulnerabilities. Take proactive steps to secure your organization with deterministic identity assurance solutions.

13:59 • 1 months ago

Dark Matter Labs

Towards an eco-social contract: the Living Stewardship Agreement

The alpha version of our Living Stewardship Agreement, being used in the field. Since the last update, Radicle Civics has been developing prototypes to realise our vision of civics set out in our blog. We’ve explored what it means to “expand our understanding of citizens […] to include humans and more-than-humans,” and “reconfigure the ways in which we collectively relate and interact with one
The alpha version of our Living Stewardship Agreement, being used in the field.

Since the last update, Radicle Civics has been developing prototypes to realise our vision of civics set out in our blog. We’ve explored what it means to “expand our understanding of citizens […] to include humans and more-than-humans,” and “reconfigure the ways in which we collectively relate and interact with one another, towards non-coercive, empathic, caring, and peer-to-peer systems.”

We believe that a non-monetary and care-based economy requires new tools to practically make sense of the world in this relational, multivalent way. This update focuses on the Living Stewardship Agreement tool we’ve been developing. For complex systems without clear boundaries, it helps actors make sense of their interdependence, and uses pro-social feedback loops to incentivise the fulfilment of mutual commitments, towards the system’s overall thriving.

We’ve started with the stewardship of river bioregions which fit this governance characteristic, but we think this approach can be applicable to different contexts.

Unbounded commons, a critical problem space for governance

While the governance of commons and common pool resources are well-established by Elinor Ostrom and others, they require “clearly defined boundaries” in both the membership and the resources governed and “must be able to exclude others” as essential criteria to their success (Ostrom, 1990). We like to call these ‘bounded commons’.

However, there is the vast remainder of commons where this criteria is not met, with ambiguous, multiple, or shifting boundaries (which we call ‘unbounded commons’). The governance model of a bounded area and membership under shared protocols is not easily applied. A river is a classic example, entangling a vast bioregion of ecologies, land uses, watersheds and shifting populations, but also manifesting in a linear, natural place and a fluid resource.

For these unbounded commons, we need to shift to a model of a networked system, focusing on relationality and interdependence between actors, nested across multiple scales. This is already being echoed in theoretical discourse, such as the Social-Ecological Systems framework which applies complex systems theory in governing humans and more-than-humans as a coherent system.

But how a centralised set of rules are enforced also needs rethinking in an unbounded context, where there is no fixed locus of authority. While digital commons are addressing this through decentralised technology, where participation is conditional on compliance, it is problematic to apply exclusion for physical places. In these cases, it may make sense to shift to a commitment-based approach, where individuals acknowledge and declare their commitments to each other for the thriving of the overall system. For this to work, information sharing across actors is critical to enable adaptive governance, where individuals adjust and coordinate their actions in feedback loops, in response to the health of the system. But not only that, social meaning must also be shared alongside this information, where a commitment is underpinned by an incentive system to fulfil them.

The challenge is how this conceptual approach can be applied in a practical context, and made intuitive so that all citizens can make sense of their role in this network of interdependence. We are strategically building the LSA to do exactly this, a practical tool for co-creating a collective picture of relationships and commitments to each other, and encouraging the practising and deepening of these commitments through feedback loops, to create an emergent ‘culture’ of stewardship. We are starting with rivers in the UK as a demonstrator for this approach, where their mismanagement arising from siloed approaches is a big part of the public debate, and is creating the demand for distributed, civil society-driven approaches to governance and stewardship.

Can commitment-based approach help realise the Rights of Nature?

This journey began when we were asking how we achieve an expanded civics that includes more-than-humans. We’ve been closely following the work of the rights of nature movement, which tackles the same question by including nature, from rivers, lagoons to ‘mother earth’ itself, as subjects that could have rights that can be enforced using the legal system. Rights of nature approaches act as interfaces between the ecosystem and the legal system of humans.

But while the groundbreaking precedents set by rights-of-nature initiatives are remarkable achievements in and of themselves, we still had reservations about how they essentially tried to shoehorn ecosystems into our human-centric (and flawed) institutions.

For example, for the granting of legal personhood to the Whanganui River, which was transformational milestone in both Indigenous and ecological rights, the governance structure introduced was very much ‘horizon 1’: it established a ‘two guardians’ office, Te Pou Tupua, which has a representative of the New Zealand Government, and another representing the Whanganui Iwi Maori tribe who have long-standing customary rights and responsibilities towards the river. The guardians are in turn supported by advisory and strategy groups.

This way of organising relationships, though creating an interface with Indigenous laws and customs, nevertheless has recognisable influences of conventional and hierarchical and bounded corporate structures. Now that rights-of-nature precedents have already been set in multiple contexts, we challenged ourselves to imagine what the next horizon approaches towards a more-than-human civics could be.

Strategies for a more-than-human civics

Our hypothesis for a ‘horizon 2’ more-than-human civics requires three elements:

Relational Civic Systems: new underlying systems of organising that move beyond simple hierarchical and bounded models, to those structured to reflect the actual complex and relational nature of our world. E.g. moving from top-down hierarchies to decentralised networks. Relational Interfaces: our existing models are entrenched in part because they are simple to understand and use (e.g. property ascribes a widely-understood set of rights and responsibilities to the owner, at the exclusion of others). In moving towards complex, more-than-human civic systems, interfaces can help the transition and make them more intuitive. These can be anything from new narratives, models, to technology. These can also serve different functions, such as representing more-than-humans, helping us overcome objectification and rebuild empathy, or even mediating between multiple actors with different needs. Commitment Engines: while many forms of voluntary actions and relationships exist in civil society, they are often still underpinned by the power of the state to be the enforcer of last resort. In Radicle Civics’ aspiration for “non-coercive, empathic, and caring” systems, we also need to move beyond these human-centric models of enforcement, especially if they are to be legitimate for a civics that includes more-than-humans. Commitment Engines explore how prosocial incentive systems, such as promises and peer recognition and review, can be used instead to create a culture of care in this new kind of civics.

As part of this process, we have been collaborating with partners such as Amsterdam University of Applied Sciences’s Civic Interaction Design group (working on the research project called Charging the Commons), Zoöp Nieuwe Instituut (with Zoönomic Institute), and the urban interfaces group at the Utrecht University (Governing the Digital Society) to explore the different manifestations of Relational Interfaces. You can read more about the workshops here and the public talk here and here.

Reimagining ‘the social contract’ for a more-than-human civics

Researching rights-of-nature initiatives also led us to revisit the debates around the nature of rights. Extending rights to living agents and even earth systems, provoked fundamental questions about rights-based frameworks, such as how their scope is defined, how they are constructed, and how they are granted and/or claimed. Leif Wenar’s Nature of Rights, building on the conceptual framework of Hohfeldian incidents, remains very influential on our thinking.

But perhaps the more practical and pressing question we were faced with was, if we declare nature has rights, how can they be made real? This thought had been bubbling up through our work on the River Dôn Project, where we have been organising workshops and events with members of the river community as part of the Festival of Debate 2023 programme in Sheffield.

At these workshops we heard from Friends of the River Cam, who invited us to experience their annual river rights declaration ceremony. On the summer solstice of 2023, a group of people who care about the River Cam gathered in a circle by the river to declare the river’s rights, reciting them collectively. These rights are:

The right to flow freely; The right to express essential functions of flooding, moving sediment, recharging groundwater and sustaining biodiversity; The right to be free from pollution; The right to replenish and be fed by sustainable aquifers; The right to native biodiversity; The right to restoration; The right to maintain connections with other streams and rivers.

Before the ceremony ended, people pledged to act as guardians of the River Cam and committed to reducing threats to its health and survival. They called on all people to engage with the river in a relationship of respect and stewardship and to cease its exploitation. We were moved by the power of this moment of ritual, not only in how it brought together the river community, but also recentred our minds on our physical and spiritual connection with the river.

Friends of the River Cam’s rights declaration ceremony, 2023.

It was also a thought-provoking moment. We can declare a river has rights, but how exactly are they manifested?

“The Rights of Man […] were supposed to be independent of all governments; but it turned out that the moment human beings lacked their own government […] no institution was willing to guarantee them. ”

— Hannah Arendt in The Origins of Totalitarianism

The current initiatives to embed rights-of-nature in law reminded us of Hannah Arendt’s concept of the ‘right to have rights’ in The Origins of Totalitarianism. While rights are claimed to be universal or natural, they rely on the power and authority of the state to be enforced. Those that are excluded from a political community, i.e. a state, also lose access to institutions that can guarantee those rights, effectively becoming rightless. While Arendt at the time was referring to stateless refugees, this can also be seen as an analogy for nature. If we extend our political communities to include nature, would that be enough to guarantee their rights?

Ideas like these draw heavily on ‘social contract theory’ which is highly influential on Western conceptions of civics. In particular, it echoes the ideas of John Locke, who believed that as part of this social contract, people consent to subject themselves to the power of government, in order for their rights to be protected.

Yet in the river contexts we are working with, especially the UK, the government has already failed to protect the health of water bodies, regardless of whether the river is deemed the subject of rights, or an object of good regulation. Granting a river rights or personhood, while creating avenues for legal action and accountability (however slow and expensive), still requires the power of the state to fix, or to compel individuals and organisations to fix our rivers. For us, this raises a question: whose responsibility is it to ensure the river has “the right to be free from pollution”? And is it enough that rights allow redress when things go wrong, or is that already too late? Shouldn’t we instead shape the way we think about everyday practices of active stewardship, and how these can be encouraged?

It is curious that social contract theorists often define organised societies against ‘the state of nature’, the chaotic and brutish world that was a free-for-all. Yet given what we know about ecosystems now, this was a caricature. Instead, we now know that ecosystems are intricately entangled interactions of many agents, each responding through feedback loops to the rest of the system, to create a delicate, dynamic equilibrium, as part of an adaptive process. So what if we answered the question of “where do rights come from?” in a more ecocentric way, rather than to impose the logic of centralised human authority onto a more-than-human world?

A new eco-social contract needs a new grammar of commitment

Based on the worldview shifts we want to realise in Radicle Civics (a world of agents entangled together in commoning relationships), we want to explore how civic systems could ensure the ultimate goal of collective thriving. Rights are but one way of ensuring this goal, by declaring a set of entitlements against which actors are held accountable. The true character of a rights-based system only is revealed in how a conflict of different actors’ rights are resolved.

Yet as discussed above, to seek remedies for violated rights may already be too late. Our hypothesis is that these rights are more meaningful when they are manifested day-to-day instead of at the point of redress. As Paul Powesland, the founder of the River Roding Trust (RRT) explained in an interview about their stewardship work in that river, “The RRT and local people are already upholding the rights of the Roding. I relate to the river as a sacred entity, and I’m doing whatever I can to uphold those rights, through law, campaigning or direct action. It comes from the wellspring of the belief that the Roding is sacred, it is a being and it does have rights, and I will manifest those in whatever way I can.”

As such, we believe we should create systems which encourage humans and more-than-humans to recognise, coordinate, and fulfil their responsibilities and obligations to each other in the system as part of an ongoing practice of stewardship. This is a mutualist approach to rights.

This mutualist idea was also inspired by what we saw in our workshop collectively mapping our entanglements with the River Don, how everyone stepped up and took responsibility towards realising the river’s rights, and practised everyday acts of care to support the collective thriving of the bioregion. Not only did this include the Don Catchment Rivers Trust, who were the driving force behind delivering ecological restoration projects, but this also included individuals such as farmers (who need to plough their land for cultivation) considering how to do so while preventing run-off into the river, to wild swimmers and walkers, whose advocacy and volunteering to improve water quality recognises the entanglement between their enjoyment of nature with the ecosystem health on which they depended. In a context where centralised authorities were failing to guarantee these conditions for the river’s thriving, the coalition of citizens and civic groups were taking up the mantle, overcoming human-centric jurisdictional boundaries and departmental silos, and each playing their part to realise the conditions needed.

We felt that this approach to rights requires new informational tools, not only for recording and communicating rights, but also practicing them in a coordinated way. The idea of a singular Charters and Declarations, to be enforced by courts, seemed at odds with our idea of rights based on everyday practices of mutual stewardship. A new grammar of the social contract and rights are needed.

Here, we were influenced by what we learned during the Holochain Foundation’s Hackathon, where we experimented with Arthur Brock, Eric Harris-Braun, and Joss Clifford-Frith. In the Hackathon, we attempted to build a tool that would support the operation of this mutualist social contract, using Holochain. Holochain is an open-source framework for building decentralised, peer-to-peer applications. In particular, its agent-centric principles define both the system architecture and the emergent social dynamics of apps based on the framework, based on “mutual sovereignty” — where individuals have agency but can freely associate by agreeing to the shared rules. This includes an individual’s sovereignty over their identity and the data they create, where they are stored on their own machine. But it also differs from other decentralised approaches, such as blockchain, where it does not require a global consensus to operate (that has its own centralising tendencies creating a single source of truth). Instead, it opts for ‘consensus-free’ design patterns, only requiring consensus at a local scale involving parties involved in a given transaction.

An (very incomplete) sample of how this relational grammar could be visualised, for a river context.

The technology’s architecture aligned with our proposed eco-social contract. At the Hackathon, we hypothesized how to structure this contract in a decentralized, peer-to-peer manner.

Agents (Users): These are the human users of the tool who participate in the stewardship ecosystem. They can do it either as themselves or also represent more-than-human actors (e.g. plants, animals, etc) — more on that below. (Under the Holochain framework, ‘agents’ only refer to the human users of the application.)

Actants: These include both the humans (including individuals and organisations) and more-than-humans who are part of this stewardship ecosystem. More-than-human actants can be represented by one or more human stewards who act and use the tool on their behalf, similar to the way interspecies councils operate.

Relationships: These reflect our entanglements in the stewardship ecosystem. These relationships are bidirectional by definition: they are in effect rights of nature reimagined in a mutualistic way. Each relationship records one condition an actant needs to thrive (their right), and how it is realised by other actant(s) commitments or promise to care. While the most obvious definition of relationships may be the material conditions needed for thriving (e.g. habitat, nutrition), the design of this model is designed to keep this open-ended for other interpretations of relationships, whether they focus on informational, cultural or spiritual conditions, intentionally without categorisation. For us, the idea of the ‘promise’ builds on cultural norms of how commitments are practiced.

This grammar of the eco-social contract becomes a relational interface: it creates a knowledge structure of the ecosystem that is explicitly centred around actants and a relationships register (rather than, say, a geographical map which emphasises territories and a top-down worldview). This also becomes a foundation for a commitment engine that encourage the practicing of these relationships:

Feedback: This is an eco-centric approach inspired by ideas of self-regulating ecosystems through feedback loops. In this case, these feedback loops are created within the knowledge structure. Any agent can submit feedback for any relationship: whether the relationship has been initiated, revised, or ended, whether the conditions to thrive have been fulfilled or breached, or even just open-ended reflections, in multiple forms of media, such as text and images.

Vouching: In line with a voluntary, non-centralising system, the knowledge structure of relationships and their feedback is also agnostic about asserting a “single source of truth”. Rather, the community is allowed to draw their own conclusions from a transparent knowledge structure. One key way is that other agents can vouch for the feedback provided, as a signal that the feedback is recognised and verified by peers.

Instead of centralised enforcement through compulsion, this open registry of peer-verified feedback allows different actants to be held accountable for their commitments through ongoing peer review and social reputation, and also encourages the rest of the community to adjust their behaviour accordingly through peer-to-peer signalling. This is based on a principle of adaptive governance, where feedback enables a continual learning process. Rather than a static charter of rights, it becomes a ‘living’ piece of collective ecosystem intelligence, where the medium of agreement has built-in mechanisms for encouraging self-compliance.

Living Stewardship Agreement: the alpha version Living Stewardship Agreement: the alpha version, showing the relationship network map, relationship, and feedback views

Based on the model above and our engagements with various river and other ecological communities, we have created a working prototype of an eco-social contract, which we call the Living Stewardship Agreement (LSA). For the sake of usability (especially in the field) and rapid iteration, we have built this prototype as a web app rather than a Holochain one, while preserving its decentralised ethos at a social level.

The LSA is not meant to be thrust upon a community in isolation; rather, it is designed to be introduced as one part of a strategy of community engagements, with the mission of bringing together civil society actors to recognise and fulfill their commitments to more-than-humans, to actualise the rights of nature.

To introduce the LSA to communities, we’ve been holding different kinds of public engagements as part of the River Dôn Project that introduce relational thinking to the public. This includes river walks, where the embodied experiences of nature can be contextualised by both visible and tacit relationships revealed by co-hosts who hold ecological knowledge (e.g. Don Catchment Rivers Trust). We’ve also held workshops, as discussed above, where stakeholders individually map their own entanglements with the river ecosystem, and deconstruct how their own care commitments are linked to other actants’ conditions to thrive, and vice versa. Communities during these engagements record these relationships on the LSA, setting up the beginnings of a relational network of their bioregion.

Once the relational network is set up, the user interface of the LSA is designed to help grow the network, and encourage the practice of its relationships and commitments. Users are presented with a (currently rudimentary) visualisation of the relationship network, showing the registered users/agents in the outer ring, the human and more-than-human actants they steward, and the relationships that connect them. At a glance, important nodes in the ecosystem can be gauged intuitively by the density of connections, such as relationships that involve many actants, or actants that impact many others.

With the further development of the LSA, we hope to explore different methods of making complex relational networks intuitive, whether it is drawing high-level insights from the network analysis, exploring alternative approaches to visualisation, or even using AI for ‘River Storyteller’ to distill the relationship dynamics into compelling narratives, that help citizens engage with the river ecosystem as a whole.

The LSA is designed to be used by stewards on a regular basis. On the home page, under the relationship network map, users are first presented with a newsfeed of the latest Feedback for the ecosystem, encouraging users to review, vouch for, and if they feel is necessary, take stewardship action in response, which in turn they can record as more feedback.

Any user can provide feedback, regardless of whether they are part of the relationship or not — after choosing a relationship on which to provide feedback, they can give their feedback a title, and for the content, they can add text or a photo. They also choose one of the predefined categories of feedback:

Sign: An actant of the relationship can add a ‘Sign’ feedback as a way of signing their consent to initiating a relationship. Human stewards could also ‘sign’ on behalf of the more-than-human actants they steward. This serves a way of validating relationships. Breach: An actant can report when the commitments of the relationship are not fulfilled, with evidence recorded in the text or photo content of the feedback. Fulfillment: An actant can report when the commitments of the relationship are fulfilled, with evidence recorded in the text or photo content of the feedback. Review: An actant can propose an amendment to the relationship, if they notice that the context or content has changed. These changes can again be consented to by ‘Sign’ feedback from the actants involved. Termination: The opposite of a ‘Sign’ feedback, if a relationship is no longer active, this type of feedback signals an actant’s intention to leave the relationship. A relationship where all its actants have given a ‘Termination’ feedback could reasonably be interpreted as ended.

Crucially, the system preserves a transparent, complete record of all feedback, but remains agnostic on a ‘single source of truth’. Instead, it allows the collective wisdom of the community to judge, based on which feedback has been most vouched for, and also where relationships have been ‘signed’ by all involved.

Users can also grow the network, when they discover previously unrecognised actants or relationships. The Actants section lists actants on the network. Users can view each actant’s page, which lists agents who steward each actant. Users can also recognise a new actant, giving it a name, photo, and inviting other agents to become stewards of the new actant.

Similarly, the Relationships section shows a list of all relationships in the system, and allows users to view each relationship’s page. This page shows which actant(s) hold the condition needed to thrive, and which actant(s) commitments to care to realise these conditions. It also shows all the feedback logged against a relationship, and allows the user to provide more. Users can also recognise a new relationship, where the relationship name, the condition and care commitments, and the actants involved are recorded.

The use of the tool records the community’s evolving knowledge of an ecosystem through the lens of relationships. This gradually builds up a valuable body of collective intelligence that shapes the stewardship response of individuals and the collective, and can be used for future applications, such as citizen science, ethnographic research or training a Storyteller AI.

Testing in context and broader applications

We have started testing it with communities in context, to validate our hypothesis of whether a tool that makes relationships and commitments tangible supports the stewardship of the ecosystem in a holistic way, while enabling self-coordination across an unbounded commons.

To begin testing, we are looking to partner with ecological stewardship communities that operate with this characteristic. This includes initial conversations with organisations such as Cody Dock, based on the Lower Lea River, who consist of both a small, dedicated biodiversity and environmentalist team and a larger but transient body of volunteers who participate in varying levels of regularity — they anticipate that the LSA, by acting as a source of information on what different stakeholders have committed to and are doing, can support the encouragement and coordination of their stewardship activities across this loose-knit community.

Surge Cooperative’s Long Wall Ecology Garden, in Newham, London. (Image credit: Surge Cooperative)

Another community we look forward to working with is Surge Cooperative, where a group of residents who live on (e.g. barges on community moorings) or near the Channelsea river in Newham, London, engage with a diverse but fluid public through their regular ‘eco-gathering’ engagement events which combine art practice and conservation, and also collectively steward areas around the river, including the Long Wall Ecology Garden.

The approach of the LSA recognises that ecological stewardship communities hold deep-rooted and diverse knowledge of their local river and have the capability for sensitive acts of restoration. But this knowledge is spread unevenly, depending on the depth and length of a member’s engagement with that community. This also means that the coordination of stewardship activities is often reliant on a few lead actors, and collective knowledge is very vulnerable to the comings and goings of community members. This partnership recognises that encouraging community-led restoration and advocacy for the river needs a space for sharing knowledge and establishing a resilient, wide-spread stewardship culture. The LSA, as part of a wider participatory approach, can become that digital space, deepening a community’s interconnectedness with water bodies and environments, and each other, through a collective process of understanding and mapping their interrelationships.

Surge Cooperative anticipates that the Living Stewardship Agreement will be a place to record the tacit knowledge held by all parts of this community who have different levels of engagement with the river. Surge Cooperative are especially interested in the possibility of the LSA being a collective place for the ‘thick’ or ‘warm data’ about the Channelsea river generated by the actants’ feedback, recognising the value of the social contexts, emotions, meanings and stories that exist around the ecosystem. After all, we believe that making sense of one’s place in the ecosystem is a social and cultural challenge beyond just a scientific one, especially in an man-made urban environment such as the Channelsea river. Through this social meaning-making is how we can truly embed a culture of stewardship.

Surge Cooperative will be testing the LSA on a long-term basis in the coming year, for at least six months — they hope that the collective intelligence generated can support their negotiations to have formalised stewardship roles with institutional stakeholders around the river. The most prominent example is that Surge Cooperative has been granted by a historic ‘Tomlin order’ from the court, granting them a right to negotiate access to river spaces with the Port of London Authority, the Channelsea’s riverbed owner, for joint stewardship. The collective intelligence accumulated through the participatory process of using the LSA can be used as an evidence base for their stewardship impact, and inform the co-development of stewardship plans in the coming months tailored around the community’s capabilities.

This will also be an opportunity for us to test the LSA approach longitudinally with a community, and we will be collecting feedback in the process to inform the next versions of the LSA and its strategic roadmap. In particular, we would like to see how the LSA has changed how individuals make sense of their place in the ecosystem’s network of interdependency, their stewardship role, and ultimately their actions. We would also like to explore to what extent the commitment engine’s information-sharing and pro-social incentives encourage and sustain stewardship activity. We hope to be conducting and publishing this research in collaboration with Dr Sharon Prendeville from Loughborough University, who connected us with Hannah White and Stephen Shiell (co-founders of Surge Cooperative), to maximise its impact not only in this water space, but also the wider discourse on Social-Ecological Systems.

Beyond ecological stewardship communities, we are also exploring how the relational structure of the LSA can be used in a variety of contexts where a reorientation from focusing on boundaries to relationships can also support more generative outcomes. These include:

Climate City Contracts: building on Dark Matter Labs’ past work with Sweden’s Viable Cities, the LSA can be used as an open digital register for recording a citizen’s civic commitments towards other actants to support climate transition, with the commitment engine’s feedback loops helping achieve self, collective, and public accountability. Crofter’s Purposeful Use Declaration: In our work with the Scottish Land Commission, we’ve identified how crofting’s notion of ‘purposeful use’ currently focuses on compliance with the Croft Commission’s requirements. By using the LSA as a register for crofters to self-declare how their ‘purposeful use’ of land benefits the croft’s wider relationships, the approach leans into the tight-knit nature of rural communities and changes the dynamic from one of compliance to pledging, encouraging peer recognition and knowledge sharing across the crofting community, creating a rich data source for articulating the added value of crofting. FreeLand and FreeHouse: One opportunity of transitioning from private to self-ownership is recognising the many relationships that exist around the land and the house. The medium of the LSA can allow these relationships and commitments to be practised in a peer-to-peer way with distributed accountability, beyond the bounded governance associated with traditional structures, which rely on fixed memberships that fractionalise and dilute ownership (e.g. boards, trustees, committees etc) rather than remove it.

If you are in a context where a relational, commitment-based governance approach can be supported by the LSA, or if you can imagine alternative applications, please reach out to us at radiclecivics@darkmatterlabs.org!

Written by Calvin Po with Fang-Jui ‘Fang-Raye’ Chang, incorporating ideas from Alexandra Bekker, Indy Johar, and showcasing Shu Yang Lin and Gurden Batra’s work building the first prototype. We would like to extend a special thanks to Arthur Brock, Eric Harris-Braun, and Joss Clifford-Frith for prototyping this idea with us, and James Lock, Alban Krashi, the Festival of Debate, Sharon Prendeville, Hannah White, and Stephen Shiell for exploring how we can explore the LSA in their contexts.

Towards an eco-social contract: the Living Stewardship Agreement was originally published in Dark Matter Laboratories on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Ocean Protocol

DF135 Completes and DF136 Launches

Predictoor DF135 rewards available. DF136 runs Apr 3— Apr 10th, 2025 1. Overview Data Farming (DF) is an incentives program initiated by ASI Alliance member, Ocean Protocol. In DF, you can earn OCEAN rewards by making predictions via ASI Predictoor. Data Farming Round 135 (DF135) has completed. DF136 is live today, April 3. It concludes on April 10th. For this DF round, Predictoor DF has
Predictoor DF135 rewards available. DF136 runs Apr 3— Apr 10th, 2025 1. Overview

Data Farming (DF) is an incentives program initiated by ASI Alliance member, Ocean Protocol. In DF, you can earn OCEAN rewards by making predictions via ASI Predictoor.

Data Farming Round 135 (DF135) has completed.

DF136 is live today, April 3. It concludes on April 10th. For this DF round, Predictoor DF has 3750 OCEAN rewards and 20,000 ROSE rewards.

2. DF structure

The reward structure for DF136 is comprised solely of Predictoor DF rewards.

Predictoor DF: Actively predict crypto prices by submitting a price prediction and staking OCEAN to slash competitors and earn.

3. How to Earn Rewards, and Claim Them

Predictoor DF: To earn: submit accurate predictions via Predictoor Bots and stake OCEAN to slash incorrect Predictoors. To claim OCEAN rewards: run the Predictoor $OCEAN payout script, linked from Predictoor DF user guide in Ocean docs. To claim ROSE rewards: see instructions in Predictoor DF user guide in Ocean docs.

4. Specific Parameters for DF136

Budget. Predictoor DF: 3750 OCEAN + 20K ROSE

Networks. Predictoor DF applies to activity on Oasis Sapphire. Here is more information about Ocean deployments to networks.

Predictoor DF rewards are calculated as follows:

First, DF Buyer agent purchases Predictoor feeds using OCEAN throughout the week to evenly distribute these rewards. Then, ROSE is distributed at the end of the week to active Predictoors that have been claiming their rewards.

Expect further evolution in DF: adding new streams and budget adjustments among streams.

Updates are always announced at the beginning of a round, if not sooner.

About Ocean, DF and ASI Predictoor

Ocean Protocol was founded to level the playing field for AI and data. Ocean tools enable people to privately & securely publish, exchange, and consume data. Follow Ocean on Twitter or TG, and chat in Discord. Ocean is part of the Artificial Superintelligence Alliance.

In Predictoor, people run AI-powered prediction bots or trading bots on crypto price feeds to earn $. Follow Predictoor on Twitter.

DF135 Completes and DF136 Launches was originally published in Ocean Protocol on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

06:02 • 1 months ago

Wednesday, 02. April 2025

UNION AVATARS

Introducing 3DAIS: Your Avatar-Powered 3D Link-in-Bio

Your online presence is more than just a list of links or a static profile. It’s your identity, your work, your creativity—everything […] The post Introducing 3DAIS: Your Avatar-Powered 3D Link-in-Bio appeared first on Union Avatars.

Your online presence is more than just a list of links or a static profile. It’s your identity, your work, your creativity—everything that makes you, you.
But what if your avatar could represent all of that in a space that truly feels like yours?

Welcome to 3DAIS: a 3D Avatar Interactive Space where your digital identity comes to life.

3DAIS: A New Way to Show Who You Are What is 3DAIS?

3DAIS is a fully customizable 3D space powered by your avatar. It combines immersive design, interactivity, and AI to create the next evolution of your online profile.

Instead of a simple landing page or link aggregator, 3DAIS gives you a virtual room where:

Visitors can move around and explore your content. Your avatar welcomes them and explains who you are. Videos, links, music, calendars, and more are embedded directly into your environment.

It’s like your personal website, portfolio, and smart assistant—merged into one interactive experience.

What Makes It Unique?

Here’s what sets 3DAIS apart:

🎭 Avatar with AI: Your avatar becomes an AI agent that can answer questions, share your content, or guide visitors around the space. 🛋️ 3D Room Customization: Choose layouts, upload media, place objects, and design the entire vibe of your space—no coding needed. 🔗 Fully Interactive: Everything is clickable—posters, video screens, portals, calendars, and even ambient sound. 🌍 Instant Access: Visitors can enter your 3DAIS via a simple link—no installation, no login required.

3DAIS isn’t just another tool. It’s an immersive, persistent presence that works for you 24/7.

Who Is It For?

Whether you’re a creator, developer, professional, or gamer—3DAIS adapts to your goals.

Creators & Artists
Showcase your work in a living portfolio with voiceovers, clickable artwork, and direct contact options. Developers & Digital Builders
Use it as a live product demo, a community hub, or a space for onboarding users. Professionals & Freelancers
Turn your 3DAIS into a smart business card—complete with a calendar, links, intro video, and downloadable files. Streamers & Influencers
Engage fans in a unique way, with branded visuals, embedded content, and a chat-ready avatar to keep the conversation going. How to Get Started

3DAIS is currently in early access, and we’re opening the doors to creators, developers, and digital professionals who want to be among the first to claim their interactive space.

Here’s how you can join:

Request access through our official form We’ll review your application and get in touch Once approved, you’ll receive the tools to create your avatar and start building your 3D space

👉 Request yours here: https://unionavatars.com/3dais

Let Your Avatar Do the Talking

The future of digital identity is not flat. It’s interactive, expressive, and immersive.
With 3DAIS, your avatar isn’t just a representation—it’s your voice, your personality, your presence online.

It’s time to turn your profile into a space.
Claim your 3DAIS and show the world who you are.

The post Introducing 3DAIS: Your Avatar-Powered 3D Link-in-Bio appeared first on Union Avatars.

iComply Investor Services Inc.

Navigating the FATF Travel Rule for FINRA and SEC Firms

Navigating the FATF Travel Rule with Ease Simplify compliance with the FATF Travel Rule using iComply's integrated platform. Automate data collection, ensure secure information sharing, and stay ahead of regulatory changes.

Meet James—a compliance officer at a FINRA-regulated firm managing security tokens and tokenized funds. James is used to navigating complex regulations, but the FATF Travel Rule has added a new layer of pressure.

It starts with a client transferring cryptoassets to another platform. James knows the Travel Rule requires his firm to collect and share key information—names, wallet addresses, and account details—every step of the way. But the process quickly becomes overwhelming.

First issue: His team is manually verifying transaction details across different tools. Next challenge: There’s no standard way to securely share data with other platforms. Final complication: International transfers bring inconsistent rules that make compliance feel like guesswork.

By the end of the day, James feels more like a crisis manager than a compliance leader.

Now imagine a different scenario—where compliance with the Travel Rule is frictionless, thanks to iComply’s integrated compliance platform.

Simplifying the Travel Rule with iComply

With iComply, James’ compliance process transforms from reactive to proactive. When a client initiates a tokenized fund transfer, the system automatically collects and verifies all required data.

Automated Data Collection: Instead of juggling spreadsheets, iComply pulls client data, validates it, and attaches it to the transaction in real time. Secure, Seamless Transmission: Information is shared through secure APIs, ensuring encrypted, standardized communication across platforms. Regulatory Intelligence: iComply stays updated on regulatory changes globally, helping James’ firm remain compliant across jurisdictions.

The result? No more manual checks, last-minute fixes, or uncertainty during audits.

Turning the Travel Rule Into a Competitive Edge

The FATF Travel Rule is a reality for SEC and FINRA-regulated firms—and non-compliance isn’t an option. But firms that adopt smart solutions like iComply can:

Enhance data security: Protect sensitive client information with automated, encrypted verification. Simplify workflows: Replace manual steps with streamlined processes that save time and reduce costs. Build trust: Show clients and regulators that your firm is proactive, not reactive, about compliance.

James no longer spends his day scrambling to keep up with regulatory demands. Instead, he has confidence that his compliance framework is future-proofed and built to scale.

The Travel Rule doesn’t have to be a burden—it can be a chance to lead. With iComply, your firm can turn complexity into confidence. Ready to make compliance a competitive advantage? Let’s talk.

06:00 • 1 months ago

HYPR

HYPR and IDEMIA Partner to Extend Smart ID Badge Security

Unlock Seamless Security: Combining Physical and Digital Access with HYPR and IDEMIA Your organization spans a physical and a virtual environment, but how well aligned are your strategies for securing both? With the rise of hybrid work models, the challenge of securing sensitive information against increasingly sophisticated online and in-person threats has become more critical than

Unlock Seamless Security: Combining Physical and Digital Access with HYPR and IDEMIA

Your organization spans a physical and a virtual environment, but how well aligned are your strategies for securing both? With the rise of hybrid work models, the challenge of securing sensitive information against increasingly sophisticated online and in-person threats has become more critical than ever.

In a groundbreaking move to address these challenges, HYPR and IDEMIA have joined forces. This powerful partnership unifies the management of credentials for both physical and digital access control on a single smart badge (the ID-One PIV Card), enabling enterprises to enhance their existing ID infrastructure with FIDO passkey protection.

Key Benefits of HYPR and IDEMIA Partnership: Enhanced Risk Reduction: By linking physical and digital identities, organizations can minimize vulnerabilities and strengthen their security posture against evolving threat landscapes. 
Simplified User Experience: Streamlining access through a unified credential system improves convenience and efficiency for both employees and administrators.
Cost Savings: Leveraging existing infrastructure and reducing time-consuming authentication processes translates to tangible cost benefits for enterprises. The New Standard in Integrated Identity and Access Management

Digital security threats are growing in sophistication as phishing attacks and social engineering techniques evolve. Traditional security measures like passwords and conventional MFA are proving inadequate against these advancements, leaving organizations exposed to significant vulnerabilities

The HYPR and IDEMIA solution introduces FIDO-certified smart badges that offer organizations enhanced protection from phishing attacks and man-in-the-middle credential stuffing. These smart-card-based MFA solutions seamlessly integrate physical facility access with digital access across multiple workstations, ensuring compatibility with all major identity security technologies. This includes the widely used physical access control protocols (MIFARE, DESfire, prox), and Identity Providers (IdPs), Identity and Access Management (IAM) systems, and Single Sign-On (SSO) services.

Furthermore, this solution is particularly beneficial for financial service organizations, aiding in compliance with Know Your Customer (KYC) and anti-money laundering (AML) regulatory requirements. HYPR and IDEMIA provide comprehensive risk management that addresses both technical and regulatory aspects of security.

How Does the HYPR | IDEMIA Integration Work?

The solution provides secure, frictionless authentication across various environments and devices, including Windows, macOS, Linux, and VDI workstations. Streamlined management enhances user adoption and minimizes administrative complexity.

Example: Employees use their IDEMIA smart cards to access office buildings and restricted areas, then seamlessly log in to corporate applications and systems using HYPR-provisioned FIDO credentials stored on the same smart card.

Example: Contractors and third-party vendors receive IDEMIA smart cards integrated with HYPR authentication, granting them access to designated locations and systems for the duration of their engagement.

Example: Hybrid workers complete identity verification and enroll device-bound passkeys with HYPR. They leverage IDEMIA smart cards for facility access and can authenticate into digital resources either with the same card or through software-based passkeys when a reader isn’t available.

Reduce IT Help Desk Burden with Streamlined User Logins

Organizations rarely address the inconveniences caused by tedious account recovery practices. IDEMIA and HYPR’s passwordless strategy alleviates the burden for the IT help desk by streamlining the organizations’ login process.

Recognizing that different organizations have unique login preferences, the IDEMIA and HYPR solution empowers enterprises and their users to select from a range of hardware and software-based authentication methods. This flexibility allows companies to tailor the authentication process to their specific needs and context.

Regardless of the mechanism an organization selects, this solution provides a single, central console that manages IDEMIA smart cards and HYPR passkeys. This unified management simplifies identity credential administration in environments where physical and virtual security procedures are still siloed. 

Reduce Identity Management Costs and Boost Productivity

Enterprises can maximize ROI with HYPR and IDEMIA’s solution, notably by capitalizing on their existing infrastructure when converting the ID badges they already use into smart badges with FIDO credentials.

Moreover, the solution demonstrably increases productivity by reducing time spent on tedious layered authentication methods like one-time passwords (OTPs), and hours-long phone calls with the IT help desk for credential recovery. By removing these inefficient tasks, businesses free up valuable time and resources that can be directed toward more strategic objectives.

Are You Solving Your Biggest Physical and Digital Access Challenges?

The collaboration between HYPR and IDEMIA marks a pivotal advancement in access management. By converging physical and digital security, this partnership not only tackles today's pressing security challenges but also charts a new course for the future of identity assurance.

Many decision-makers operate under the belief that stronger security necessitates compromising user experience. However, the HYPR and IDEMIA partnership shatters this notion, demonstrating that organizations can achieve both security and a seamless user experience. It's a dual victory for enterprises aiming to excel in an era where security and convenience are equally paramount.

Contact us to unlock the power of a comprehensive security solution and embrace the future of access management.
